title: Kayshon Boutte reflects on his forgotten history as an elite prospect
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: Kayshon Boutte was once a top high school wide receiver prospect, drawing comparisons to Stefon Diggs.
An ankle injury in college impacted Boutte's draft position, leading to his selection in the sixth round by the Patriots.
Boutte has established himself as a key receiver for the Patriots, highlighted by a strong preseason and season opener.

title: Hasbro is relocating its headquarters to Boston’s Seaport
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Hasbro is relocating its headquarters from Pawtucket, Rhode Island to 400 Summer St. in Boston's Seaport by end of 2026.
The new Boston headquarters will occupy 265,000 square feet and house around 700 full-time employees.
Massachusetts officials, including Gov. Maura Healey, welcome Hasbro's move, citing job creation and economic growth.

title: Wu heads into preliminary election with massive 50-point lead over Kraft
author: Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Mayor Michelle Wu leads Josh Kraft by 50 points in a new Emerson College poll ahead of Boston's preliminary election.
Wu's support increased from a 30-point lead in July to 72% among likely voters, compared to Kraft's 22%.
Other candidates, Domingos DaRosa and Robert Cappucci, have not surpassed single-digit support, making Wu and Kraft likely general election candidates.

title: Dunkin’ franchisee closes down production plant, lays off 74 employees
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: NGP Management is closing its Haverhill Dunkin' production facility, resulting in 74 layoffs by early November.
The closure affects 45 production workers, 21 drivers, and other staff; none are unionized.
A new 100,000 sq. ft. Dunkin' plant is under construction in Haverhill, opening by year-end to serve Merrimack Valley stores.

title: Bill Belichick statue at Gillette? Here’s what more than 1,000 readers said.
author: Annie Jonas
bullets: A poll of 1,075 readers revealed 46% support for a Bill Belichick statue at Gillette Stadium.
Some fans cite Belichick's role in six Super Bowl wins, while others highlight his lack of fan connection.
Debate arises on whether Belichick and Brady should be equally honored for their contributions to the Patriots.

title: Pair from Brighton facing charges in string of handicap placard thefts
author: Heather Alterisio
bullets: Two Brighton residents, Andrea Doucette-Keating and Zachary Shelton, face charges in connection to 19 handicap placard thefts.
Police identified Doucette-Keating as the main thief and Shelton as the organizer who supplied tools and distributed stolen placards.
Authorities recovered multiple stolen placards, tools, and illegal items during searches of Shelton's residence and vehicle.

title: Why did the Patriots abandon the run against the Raiders? Mike Vrabel explains.
author: Khari A. Thompson
bullets: The Patriots focused on passing with 46 attempts from Drake Maye in their loss to the Raiders.
Rookies TreVeyon Henderson and Antonio Gibson, along with Rhamondre Stevenson, combined for only 18 carries for 60 yards.
Coach Mike Vrabel cited a need for more efficient running and better offensive line blocking as key issues.

title: The T’s ‘fare engagement representatives’ are hitting the streets today. Here’s what to expect.
author: Abby Patkin
bullets: MBTA begins crackdown on fare evasion with 'fare engagement representatives' issuing warnings and fines for unpaid fares.
Fare violators face a $50 fine for each of the first three offenses, rising to $100 for subsequent violations.
Massachusetts decriminalized fare evasion in 2021; MBTA now emphasizes fare payments to support transit investments.

title: Kendrick Bourne reportedly agrees to one-year contract with 49ers
author: Hayden Bird
bullets: Kendrick Bourne signs a one-year contract with the 49ers worth up to $5 million.
Bourne was released by the Patriots at his request to seek more playing time elsewhere.
Bourne could start quickly for the 49ers due to Jauan Jennings' Week 1 shoulder injury.

title: The Ocean Club restaurant opens in Martha’s Vineyard landmark bank building
author: Frances Klemm
bullets: The Ocean Club, led by chef Marc Orfaly, opened Aug. 27 in a historic bank building in Vineyard Haven.
The restaurant features a seasonal menu focused on seafood and pasta, with future plans for a raw bar.
Renovations preserved original bank features, including a stained glass ceiling and a vault used as a wine cellar.
